message_1: Calculate the amount of heat required to melt 20 grams of ice at 0°C and convert it to liquid water at 0°C. The enthalpy of fusion of water is 6.01 kJ/mol. Show all the steps of your calculations.
message_2:
To calculate the amount of heat required to melt 20 grams of ice at 0°C and convert it to liquid water at 0°C, we will use the formula:

q = n × ΔHf

where q is the heat required, n is the number of moles of the substance, and ΔHf is the enthalpy of fusion.

Step 1: Calculate the number of moles of ice
The molar mass of water (H2O) is 18.015 g/mol. To find the number of moles (n) in 20 grams of ice, we will use the formula:

n = mass / molar mass

n = 20 g / 18.015 g/mol
n ≈ 1.11 moles

Step 2: Calculate the heat required
Now that we have the number of moles, we can use the formula q = n × ΔHf to find the heat required to melt the ice:

q = 1.11 moles × 6.01 kJ/mol
q ≈ 6.67 kJ

Therefore, approximately 6.67 kJ of heat is required to melt 20 grams of ice at 0°C and convert it to liquid water at 0°C.
